displayed_text: Patient: Um hum. Doctor: So probably one guy benefited and one guy has not. Uh, we’re about to do a third guy probably in the next few weeks. So, uh, but I think that trial I would probably want you to have at least been on one of the hormone drugs first. Patient: Um hum. Doctor: Because those drugs do improve how long people live and are relatively easy. So I think I would, even though that’s my trial, the bone marrow transplant trial, it’s designed for people like you who are young- Patient: Um hum. Doctor: Um, the, uh, I would rather first do something that at least has a track record of success. Does that make sense? Patient: Um hum. How do you feel about it? She wanted to end all this crazy stuff. Family Member: I don’t think it’s crazy stuff. (Laughter) Doctor: Yeah. I get, you know, I think in the trials that they did with these drugs, and these are now not even new anymore They’re sort of old now. We’ve been doing this a long time. Patient: Um hum. Doctor: Uh, they did trials in men before chemotherapy and after chemotherapy. It’s kind of the dividing line. And in both cases, they saw that the men responded very well, and that it improved survival of the men. Family Member: Um hum.

Patient: Uh well like one of them know about you know my surgery, but you know sometimes you know I don’t feel comfortable talking to some people about what I been… Doctor: I understand, right, I understand. Patient: You know and… Doctor: So. Patient: You know I’m just, I’m glad to be alive. (Laughs) Doctor: Right. Patient: <___> what I’m sayin’. Doctor: Right. To try to speed this along I think I’ll refer you to Dr. L____. He’s our person here who takes care of sexual dysfunction. Patient: Um hmmm. Doctor: Uh Because uh you know it seems like that certainly is something that concerns you very much. Patient: Yeah, yeah. Doctor: And so…

Patient: This would be two. Doctor: Yeah. We’ll do three more of this um because again there’s a little interruption, there’s radiation, you know so we’ll just do four total Patient: Yeah okay. Family Member: Okay. Patient: Did you make a comment once that um that chemo doesn’t go up the skull or up to the brain or something like that? Doctor: It doesn’t typically penetrate to go to brain tissue, but it will penetrate to skull because that’s part of the bone. Patient: Okay. Doctor: So we’ll target the area even though you had it radiated. It still would be going around Patient: Okay. Doctor: the neck. It just doesn’t go into the brain. Patient: I don’t want that to come back. Doctor: Yes, we don’t want it to come back either.
